json_results.Structural Analysis of Source Molecule: The molecule contains a bicyclic aromatic core (quinoline-like) with a carbamate group (C(=O)O) linked to a trifluoroethylamine side chain. A trifluoromethyl-substituted aryl ether (O-linked aryl-CF3) is attached to the bicyclic system. The structure includes multiple fluorine atoms (CF3 groups) contributing to high lipophilicity and potential metabolic stability.
json_results.Property Analysis: DRD2 activity requires balanced lipophilicity, hydrogen-bonding capability, and proper steric fit. The carbamate group may limit metabolic stability, while excessive fluorine content (high logP) could reduce solubility and brain penetration. The rigid aryl ether linker might restrict conformational adaptability for receptor binding.
json_results.Limitation in Source Molecule for Proper: 1. Carbamate group (C(=O)O) is prone to hydrolysis, reducing metabolic stability. 2. Trifluoroethylamine and aryl-CF3 groups increase logP excessively, risking poor solubility. 3. Aryl ether linker limits conformational flexibility, potentially reducing DRD2 binding affinity.
json_results.Optimization for Source Molecule: 1. Replace carbamate with a stable amide (C(=O)NH) to improve metabolic stability. 2. Replace one CF3 group with a chlorine to lower logP while retaining hydrophobicity. 3. Substitute the aryl ether (O-linker) with a methylene group (CH2) to enhance rigidity and reduce metabolic cleavage. 4. Introduce a piperazine ring to improve basicity and receptor interaction.
